intro: Brassica oleracea var. loudonii, commonly known as the Chinese kale or kale cabbage, is a leafy vegetable characterized by its thick, dark green, crinkled leaves. It is native to East Asia and is cultivated for its edible leaves, which are rich in nutrients such as vitamins A, C, and K. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, yellow flowers in the spring. It thrives in cool climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. This variety is a member of the Brassicaceae family, known for its cruciferous characteristics and distinctive mustard-like odor when crushed.
